title: 111_s3238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The tragic deaths on September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon are acknowledged. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 took heroic action to prevent the aircraft from being used as a weapon, recognizing the potential danger. It is fitting to recognize their sacrifice with an appropriate medal in light of the unprecedented attacks on the United States on September 11, 2001. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 to receive Congressional Medals. The President is authorized to award the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and memorials in recognition of their sacrifices on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs for the presentations. The Secretary will strike 3 designs of medals to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, United Airlines Flight 93, and the Pentagon. The Secretary will consult with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties to determine the design of silver and gold medals for individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Eligibility for the medal will be determined by the Secretary. Eligibility for the medal will be determined by the Secretary, in consultation with other relevant officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS. The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of medals for recipients who responded to the 9/11 attacks, to be displayed at their duty stations. Recipients include public safety, emergency, and government workers who perished as a result of the terrorist act. Establishment of lists of recipients. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal and duplicate medal recipients. Consultation with relevant offices will be done to determine eligibility. The Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal and duplicate medal recipients, in consultation with relevant offices. The lists are not subject to judicial review. If anyone becomes eligible for a medal or duplicate, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
